content:
On Jan. 2, 2024, a video was posted to X, formerly known as Twitter, showing former U.S. President Bill Clinton shaking hands with hospital workers. The account simply captioned the video, "Bill?"
 (X user @malachimaxeyusa)
While the video itself appeared rather innocent, the replies to the tweet and other reposts of the same video revealed that viewers thought it was theoretically showing Clinton engaging in some sort of public relations campaign to distract the news media and general population from his ties to the late, disgraced financier and sex criminal Jeffrey Epstein. As one repost put it, Clinton was engaging in a "Harvey Weinstein fake hurt scam." Epstein was back in the news after a judge ordered documents unsealed in a lawsuit filed against his associate/partner in crime, Ghislaine Maxwell.
The video was real, but the insinuations about it were false. 
Snopes found the same moment shown in the X clip in a video on CNN Politics. In that video, which was posted on Oct. 17, 2021, Clinton walked out of a California hospital after being treated for an infection. We cross-checked that CNN clip with an Al Jazeera article documenting the same event. Because the video is real, but the context around it is verifiably false, we have rated this claim as "Miscaptioned."
Clinton has been the frequent subject of claims spread online connecting him to Epstein and Maxwell.
Among the claims was a video of Hillary Clinton supposedly threatening to assassinate anyone who connected her husband with Epstein (false) or photos of Epstein with the former president (true). A 2019 article from The New York Times uncovered more details about the connections between the two men.

original_rationales.main_rational: The video was real, but the insinuations about it were false.
original_rationales.addtional_rational1: As one repost put it, Clinton was engaging in a "Harvey Weinstein fake hurt scam."
original_rationales.addtional_rational2: Because the video is real, but the context around it is verifiably false, we have rated this claim as "Miscaptioned."
original_rationales.addtional_rational3: Clinton has been the frequent subject of claims spread online connecting him to Epstein and Maxwell.

summary_rationales.synthesized_rationale: The claim regarding the video of Bill Clinton greeting medical workers to distract from his connections to Jeffrey Epstein was rated as 'Miscaptioned' because although the video itself was real, the context and insinuations surrounding it were false, as verified by fact-checkers Snopes and corroborated by other media sources. The article clarifies that the video actually depicted Clinton leaving a hospital in California after receiving medical treatment, contradicting the misleading narratives circulating online. This discrepancy between the actual event shown in the video and the misleading implications attributed to it justifies the 'Miscaptioned' rating.

detailed_reasons.reason1: The video of Bill Clinton interacting with medical workers was found to be genuine and captured him leaving a hospital after medical treatment, which contradicted the false narrative suggesting he was engaging in a calculated public relations ploy to divert attention from his association with Jeffrey Epstein.
detailed_reasons.reason2: Contrary to the claims insinuated by online viewers and reposts, fact-checkers like Snopes verified the authenticity of the video by cross-referencing it with other media sources such as CNN Politics and Al Jazeera. This verification process confirmed the real context of the video and exposed the misinterpretations surrounding it.
detailed_reasons.reason3: The article emphasizes that despite the video being authentic, the misrepresentations circulating online linked to Clinton's connections to Epstein and Maxwell were inaccurate. This discrepancy between the veracity of the video itself and the misleading interpretations attached to it justifies the 'Miscaptioned' rating since the content was misrepresented and taken out of context.
